notes: Eleventh-generation Civic. Available as sedan or hatchback. Type R returns with 315 hp. Manual transmission available. Best-selling compact car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Civic article, January 2025 revision.

Eleventh-generation Accord. Available with turbo I4 or hybrid. Hybrid system standard on many trims. Mid-size sedan leader. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Accord article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth-generation CR-V. Available with turbo or hybrid powertrain. Best-selling crossover in America. AWD available. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda CR-V article, January 2025 revision.
Second-generation HR-V for North America. Larger than global model. Subcompact crossover. AWD available. Entry-level Honda SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda HR-V article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth-generation Pilot. Three-row seating for 8. V6-only powertrain. TrailSport off-road variant. Family SUV leader. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Pilot article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Passport. Two-row SUV based on Pilot platform. AWD standard. TrailSport off-road variant. More rugged than CR-V. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Passport article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Ridgeline refresh. Unibody construction. AWD standard. In-bed trunk. Dual-action tailgate. Unique truck design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Ridgeline article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Odyssey refresh. Seven or eight-passenger seating. V6-only powertrain. Magic Slide second-row seats. Premium family minivan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Odyssey article, January 2025 revision.

Honda's first mass-market battery electric vehicle. Co-developed with GM on Ultium platform. 85 kWh battery pack. Up to 296-mile range (FWD). High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Prologue article, January 2025 revision.
